AduÌpáº¹ puÌpá»Ì€. BaÌkan naÌaÌ€, a ki yiÌn kaÌaÌ€bá»Ì€ siÌ ibi ifilá»Ìláº¹Ì€ raÌnpáº¹Ì yiÌ€iÌ. áº¸GBáº¸Ì AÌ€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ was founded in 2017 as a response to the myriads of challenges and threats facing the preservation and survival of the YoruÌ€baÌ culture and language. Many people have lamented and written extensively about how Africans are gradually killing their culture and language as a result of excessive and unrestricted patronage of foreign ones and that of former colonial masters. Apart from the fact that most people nowadays cannot even read in their indigenous languages, there is also a greater concern as regards the waning presence of quality literature materials in these languages. And this has no doubt impeded our ability to sufficiently and originally contribute to global discussions and solutions. For instance, just as we have robotics, we also have the concept of á¹¢iÌ€giÌ€diÌ€ in the YoruÌ€baÌ culture as a programmable auto-bot capable of performing all of the functions of a robot â€“ and even more! But lack of preservation of our indigenous knowledge and practices â€“ of which language and literature plays a principal role â€“ has not afforded us enough opportunities to harness our rich heritage. á¹¢uÌ€gbá»Ìn, kaÌ€kaÌ€ kiÌ a juÌ€má»Ì€ darapá»Ì€ má»Ìn aÌ€wá»n tiÌ yio maa raÌhuÌ€n nipa gbogbo aÌ€wá»n iÌ€peÌ€niÌjaÌ€ yiÌ€iÌ, a ni ka fi ookan kuÌn eeji ka kuku fi áº¸gbáº¹Ì AÌ€táº¹Ìláº¹wá»Ì leÌláº¹ lati á¹£e aayan fun á»já» á»la wa ati ti aá¹£a wa. AÌ€táº¹Ìláº¹wá»Ì jáº¹Ì áº¹gbáº¹Ì tiÌ a daÌ siÌláº¹Ì€ tâ€™oÌ waÌ€ fuÌn iÌ€raÌ€padaÌ€ aÌ€ti iÌ€gbeÌlaÌrugáº¹ aÌ€á¹£aÌ€ YoruÌ€baÌ. Iá¹£áº¹Ì AÌ€táº¹Ìláº¹wá»Ì ni: Awa ti a jáº¹Ì aká»ni áº¸GBáº¸Ì AÌ€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ jáº¹Ì máº¹rin ğŸ˜€ : BUSINESS OF THE DAY: AÌ€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ PEÌLEÌBEÌ In furtherance of our stated objectives above, we started our first project â€“ a collection of thoughts written in the Yoruba language. We went through a lot of challenges in putting the book together but we are happy it is finally here. And we are glad to inform you that we are launching the book, AÌ€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ PEÌLEÌBEÌ. AÌ€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ PEÌLEÌBEÌ is a collection of poems, short stories and articles written in the YoruÌ€baÌ language from about 40 contributors within and outside Nigeria. The book showcases established and emerging names of writers of YoruÌ€baÌ origin. The book was edited by the duo of á»ŒÌ€ráº¹Ìdá»laÌ Ibrahim and Rasaq Malik. The book has received accolades â€“ within and outside the country â€“ from people like Mr. Ká»ÌlaÌ TuÌbá»Ì€suÌn (The founder of Yorubaname.com and the 2016 recipient of the Premio Ostana awards) who introduced the book and Professor Moyá»Ì€ á»ŒÌ€káº¹ÌdiÌ€ji from the University of Texas, Austin who wrote the foreword. Others who have praised the initiative include Saheed AdeÌriÌ€ntá»Ì, Associate Professor from Western Carolina University, USA; Ká»Ì€ngá»Ì á»ŒÌ€rá»Ì€ (Graduate Assistant, University of Birmingham, Member (Yoruba Studies Association of Nigeria (YSAN) and Former Language Instructor, American Council on the Teaching of Foreign); AÌ€aÌ€ráº¹ AjiÌbá»ÌlaÌ IÌ€shá»Ì€laÌ (President, Yoruba Studentsâ€™ Association (2010-2011) and from many more. With this publication, it is our hope to re-fill the dying passion for the Yoruba language amongst our youths, to reignite the discussion and attention surrounding the publication of Yoruba literature and lastly to inspire other youths like us that the future has already started and â€“ like John Legend lamented in his song â€“ â€œWe are already lateâ€. We want to inspire a renewed interest, focus, committment and contributions to the preservation and promotion of our indiginous culture, not just from YoruÌ€baÌ youths but from others across different African cultures. Mo sÃ¬ rÃ² pÃ© arÃ¬nrÃ¬n-Ã jÃ² nÃ¡Ã  gbá»Ìdá»Ì€ jáº¹Ì áº¹Ì€yin gan alÃ¡ra, bÃ ba bÃ bÃ¡ mÃ¬i á»Ì€wá»Ìn, nÃ­torÃ­ Ã wá»n nÇ¹kan wá»Ì€nyÃ­ jáº¹Ì ohun tÃ­ o á¹£e sÃ­ wa Ã ti ohun tÃ­ a á¹£e sÃ­ á». The Childâ€™s story Once upon a time, a good many years ago, there was a traveller, and he set out upon a journey. It was a magic journey, and was to seem very long when he began it, and very short when he got half way through. He travelled along a rather dark path for some little time, without meeting anything, until at last he came to a beautiful child. So he said to the child, â€œWhat do you do here?â€ And the child said, â€œI am always at play. Come and play with me!â€ So, he played with that child, the whole day long, and they were very merry. The sky was so blue, the sun was so bright, the water was so sparkling, the leaves were so green, the flowers were so lovely, and they heard such singing-birds and saw so many butteries, that everything was beautiful. This was in fine weather. When it rained, they loved to watch the falling drops, and to smell the fresh scents. When it blew, it was delightful to listen to the wind, and fancy what it said, as it came rushing from its homeâ€“ where was that, they wondered!â€“whistling and howling, driving the clouds before it, bending the trees, rumbling in the chimneys, shaking the house, and making the sea roar in fury. But, when it snowed, that was best of all; for, they liked nothing so well as to look up at the white flakes falling fast and thick, like down from the breasts of millions of white birds; and to see how smooth and deep the drift was; and to listen to the hush upon the paths and roads. They had plenty of the finest toys in the world, and the most astonishing picture-books: all about scimitars and slippers and turbans, and dwarfs and giants and genii and fairies, and blue- beards and bean-stalks and riches and caverns and forests and Valentines and Orsons: and all new and all true. But, one day, of a sudden, the traveller lost the child. He called to him over and over again, but got no answer. So, he went upon his road, and went on for a little while without meeting anything, until at last he came to a handsome boy. So, he said to the boy, â€œWhat do you do here?â€ And the boy said, â€œI am always learning. Come and learn with me.â€ So he learned with that boy about Jupiter and Juno, and the Greeks and the Romans, and I donâ€™t know what, and learned more than I could tellâ€“or he either, for he soon forgot a great deal of it. But, they were not always learning; they had the merriest games that ever were played. They rowed upon the river in summer, and skated on the ice in winter; they were active afoot, and active on horseback; at cricket, and all games at ball; at prisonerâ€™s base, hare and hounds, follow my leader, and more sports than I can think of; nobody could beat them. They had holidays too, and Twelfth cakes, and parties where they danced till midnight, and real Theatres where they saw palaces of real gold and silver rise out of the real earth, and saw all the wonders of the world at once. As to friends, they had such dear friends and so many of them, that I want the time to reckon them up. They were all young, like the handsome boy, and were never to be strange to one another all their lives through. Still, one day, in the midst of all these pleasures, the traveller lost the boy as he had lost the child, and, after calling to him in vain, went on upon his journey. So he went on for a little while without seeing anything, until at last he came to a young man. So, he said to the young man, â€œWhat do you do here?â€ And the young man said, â€œI am always in love. Come and love with me.â€ So, he went away with that young man, and presently they came to one of the prettiest girls that ever was seenâ€“just like Fanny in the corner thereâ€“and she had eyes like Fanny, and hair like Fanny, and dimples like Fannyâ€™s, and she laughed and coloured just as Fanny does while I am talking about her. So, the young man fell in love directlyâ€“just as Somebody I wonâ€™t mention, the first time he came here, did with Fanny. Well! he was teased sometimesâ€“just as Somebody used to be by Fanny; and they quarrelled sometimesâ€“just as Somebody and Fanny used to quarrel; and they made it up, and sat in the dark, and wrote letters every day, and never were happy asunder, and were always looking out for one another and pretending not to, and were engaged at Christmas-time, and sat close to one another by the fire, and were going to be married very soonâ€“all exactly like Somebody I wonâ€™t mention, and Fanny! But, the traveller lost them one day, as he had lost the rest of his friends, and, after calling to them to come back, which they never did, went on upon his journey. So, he went on for a little while without seeing anything, until at last he came to a middle-aged gentleman. So, he said to the gentleman, â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ And his answer was, â€œI am always busy. Come and be busy with me!â€ So, he began to be very busy with that gentleman, and they went on through the wood together. The whole journey was through a wood, only it had been open and green at first, like a wood in spring; and now began to be thick and dark, like a wood in summer; some of the little trees that had come out earliest, were even turning brown. The gentleman was not alone, but had a lady of about the same age with him, who was his Wife; and they had children, who were with them too. So, they all went on together through the wood, cutting down the trees, and making a path through the branches and the fallen leaves, and carrying burdens, and working hard. Sometimes, they came to a long green avenue that opened into deeper woods. Then they would hear a very little, distant voice crying, â€œFather, father, I am another child! Stop for me!â€ And presently they would see a very little figure, growing larger as it came along, running to join them. When it came up, they all crowded round it, and kissed and welcomed it; and then they all went on together. Sometimes, they came to several avenues at once, and then they all stood still, and one of the children said, â€œFather, I am going to sea,â€ and another said, â€œFather, I am going to India,â€ and another, â€œFather, I am going to seek my fortune where I can,â€ and another, â€œFather, I am going to Heaven!â€ So, with many tears at parting, they went, solitary, down those avenues, each child upon its way; and the child who went to Heaven, rose into the golden air and vanished. Whenever these partings happened, the traveller looked at the gentleman, and saw him glance up at the sky above the trees, where the day was beginning to decline, and the sunset to come on. He saw, too, that his hair was turning grey. But, they never could rest long, for they had their journey to perform, and it was necessary for them to be always busy. At last, there had been so many partings that there were no children left, and only the traveller, the gentleman, and the lady, went upon their way in company. And now the wood was yellow; and now brown; and the leaves, even of the forest trees, began to fall. So, they came to an avenue that was darker than the rest, and were pressing forward on their journey without looking down it when the lady stopped. â€œMy husband,â€ said the lady. â€œI am called.â€ They listened, and they heard a voice a long way down the avenue, say, â€œMother, mother!â€ It was the voice of the first child who had said, â€œI am going to Heaven!â€ and the father said, â€œI pray not yet. The sunset is very near. I pray not yet!â€ But, the voice cried, â€œMother, mother!â€ without minding him, though his hair was now quite white, and tears were on his face. Then, the mother, who was already drawn into the shade of the dark avenue and moving away with her arms still round his neck, kissed him, and said, â€œMy dearest, I am summoned, and I go!â€ And she was gone. And the traveller and he were left alone together. And they went on and on together, until they came to very near the end of the wood: so near, that they could see the sunset shining red before them through the trees. Yet, once more, while he broke his way among the branches, the traveller lost his friend. He called and called, but there was no reply, and when he passed out of the wood, and saw the peaceful sun going down upon a wide purple prospect, he came to an old man sitting on a fallen tree. So, he said to the old man, â€œWhat do you do here?â€ And the old man said with a calm smile, â€œI am always remembering. Come and remember with me!â€ So the traveller sat down by the side of that old man, face to face with the serene sunset; and all his friends came softly back and stood around him. The beautiful child, the handsome boy, the young man in love, the father, mother, and children: every one of them was there, and he had lost nothing. So, he loved them all, and was kind and forbearing with them all, and was always pleased to watch them all, and they all honoured and loved him. And I think the traveller must be yourself, dear Grandfather, because this what you do to us, and what we do to you. -Charles Dickens (Dickens short story) OlÃºwÃ¡fáº¹Ìmi Káº¹ÌhÃ¬ndÃ© jáº¹Ì á»má» Ã¬pÃ­nláº¹Ì€ á»ŒÌ€yá»Ì, tÃ­ a bÃ­ nÃ­ Ã¬lÃº ÃŒbÃ dÃ n. Being an address delivered by the cofounders of Atelewo, Rasaq Malik and Ibrahim á»ŒÌ€ráº¹Ìdá»laÌ at the Press Conference organised to mark the 5th year anniversary of ATELEWO. On the 1st of June, 2017, we started Ã€Táº¸ÌLáº¸Wá»ŒÌ Cultural Initiative as a response to the myriads of challenges and threats facing the preservation and survival of the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ culture and language. It is a well-known fact that a majority of Nigerians and Africans at large are unable to read or write in their indigenous African languages, this is not helped by education policies that do not mandate students to learn an African language up to secondary school level and the waning presence of quality literature materials in these languages. As a course changing initiative, we started Ã€Táº¸Láº¸Wá»ŒÌ Ìto solve some of these problems by making it a platform dedicated to the reviving and repositioning of the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ culture with the mission to provide a platform for stoking interest and generating fulfilling engagements with the dynamics of the YorÃ¹ba Ìculture through competitions, lectures, dialogues, and regular meetups; to provide a platform for the documentation and preservation of YorÃ¹ba Ìancient knowledge, culture, and language in keeping pace with technological advancement; and to rekindle peopleâ€™s interest in YorÃ¹bÃ¡ literature by organising readings, making YorÃ¹ba Ìliterature accessible and publishing new voices in the YorÃ¹ba ÌLanguage. For the past five years, we have been committed to these ideals and mission and we have strived to ensure we donâ€™t depart from them. For five years, we have been at the forefront of promoting YoruÌ€bÃ¡ literary culture through a series of projects involving online publishing, research, competitions and YorÃ¹bÃ¡ books promotion. For five years, we have organised both free and paid YorÃ¹bÃ¡ literacy training events online and offline. For five years, we have worked with national and international organisations to translate and create messages promoting values in the health, education and agriculture sectors. For five years, we have committed to works documenting the lives of the old veteran YorÃ¹bÃ¡ authors and academics. For five years, we have consulted and provided valuable support, insights and advocacies for various YorÃ¹bÃ¡ projects and initiatives nationally and internationally. For five years, we have provided a platform for culture and language enthusiasts to engage in rich dialogues about issues relating to and affecting the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ people. In line with our goals and objectives, Ã€Táº¸Láº¸Wá»ŒÌÌ launched the annual â€œÃ€Táº¸Láº¸Wá»ŒÌÌ PRIZE FOR YORÃ™BÃ LITERATUREâ€ in 2020. The competition is open to previously unpublished writers working in YorÃ¹ba Ìlanguage. The Ã€TEÄ¹áº¸áºˆÌÃ“ PRIZáº¸ FOR YORÃ™BÃ LITERATURE is instituted to address some of the problemsâ€“committed publishers, distribution, cultivating invested readerships, etc.â€“that creative writing in YorÃ¹bÃ¡ faces. The Ã€TEÄ¹áº¸áºˆÌÃ“ PRIZáº¸ FOR YORÃ™BÃ LITERATURE intends to rejuvenate the more than the century-old, vibrant, universally praised, and unquestionably rich YorÃ¹bÃ¡ literary culture. For the first edition, entries were opened for writers to submit to poetry, prose and drama categories. After the keenly contested competition, we had a total of five winners. Mustapha Sherif emerged as the overall winner for his manuscript â€œOrin EwÃ¬ Aká»danâ€. Other winners are á¹¢eun AdÃ©jÃ re (Tâ€™áº¹nÃ­kÃº LÃ³ gbÃ©), Amos á»ŒlÃ¡tÃºnjÃ­ PÃ³pÃ³á»lÃ¡ (AkÃ­nkanjÃº á»Œdáº¹ NÃ­nÃº IgbÃ³ Ã€má»Ì€táº¹ÌkÃ¹n), Sodiq Lawal (KoÃ³wÃ¨ Åƒ kÃ©Ã©), Agboá»lÃ¡ Ã€yÃ¡ndÃ¬ran (Ã“ JÃ¡ Sá»Ìpáº¹Ì). The overall winner received a cash prize of 50,000 Naira while the rest of the winners received plaques and book prizes. For the second edition, we added a new category called â€œTranslationâ€ for entries that translated works in other languages to the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ language. And at the end of the process, we equally had five winners. Waliyullah Tunde Abiimbola emerged as the overall winner for his manuscript, Oko áº¸ranko, a YorÃ¹bÃ¡ translation of George Orwellâ€™s â€œAnimal Farmâ€. Other winners are Kafilah Ayá»Ì€bÃ¡mi Fashola (Ã€báº¹Ì€nÃ­), BÃ¡kÃ¡rÃ¨ Wahab TÃ¡Ã­wÃ² (Atewolara Akewi-Akowe), AnÃ­fowÃ³á¹£e Zainab OlÃºwafÃºnmilá»ÌlÃ¡ (Igbeyin Owuro) and Abdulkareem Jeleel á»Œlasunkanmi (EwÃ¬ KÃ²bá»má»jáº¹Ì). The overall winner received a cash prize of 100,000 Naira while the rest of the winners received a plaque and 50,000 Naira each. Today, we are happy to announce the launch of the 3rd edition. And weâ€™re calling on previously unpublished writers working in the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ language to put in their works. Weâ€™ll be accepting submissions from the 1st of June to the 30th of October. The judging process will commence on the 1st of November to the 30th of January while the award ceremony will happen in Ibadan on the 21st of February, 2023 in commemoration of International Mother Language Day. With the support of our stakeholders, we are also happy to announce that the prize has increased and the overall winner will be going home with 250,000 Naira and his book will be published in hard copies, while three other winners will go home with 100,000 Naira each. More information can be found at www.atelewo.org/idije-iwe. For the past five years, we have been very fortunate to have the support of wonderful people who are equally lovers of the YorÃ¹bÃ¡ language and culture. No doubt, we have done quite a lot in this space but much of what we have done would not have been possible without their support. First of all, we will like to appreciate Professor Adeleke Adeeko, Humanities Distinguished Professor & Department Interim Chair at the Ohio State University. Professor AdÃ©áº¹Ì€ká»Ì is our patron and he has done a lot to provide us with guidance, network and support for our various activities in the last three years. We will also like to appreciate Mr á»ŒlÃ¡dÃ©lÃ© OnÃ­lÃ©-Ere for his support for the organisation, most especially in the development and sustenance of our annual prize for YorÃ¹bÃ¡ literature. Others we will like to appreciate are Professor Ã€rÃ¬npÃ© AdÃ©jÃ¹má»Ì€, Dr Tosin Gbogi, Dr James Yeku, Dr Gbenga Bamgbose, Jumoke Verissimo, Molara Wood, Kola Tubosun, Akin Adesokan, Damilá»ÌlÃ¡ AdÃ©bá»Ìná»Ì€já», Professor Moyá»Ì€ Ã’kÃ©dÃ¬jÃ­, Fatoba Onala, Gbenga Adeoba, Ayo Adams, Deji Akomolafe, Professor Saheed Aderinto, Odolaye Aremu, Musiliu Dasofunjo and many others too numerous to mention. Similarly, we will like to appreciate organisations like Goethe-Institut, The Artivists, Oyo Inisghts, Yoruba Name, Distrifoods, Building Nations Initiative, HueNation Agency, Petspoint Recycling and others. Thank you for the trust and thank you for not leaving us to do it alone. For the next five years, in addition to making our existing works sustainable, we are also looking at building a state of the art Cultural Innovation hub dedicated to advancing the course of African cultures while leveraging innovation and technology. The Cultural Innovation Hub will be a place for young people to collaborate physically and virtually to develop the next startup, idea, project and initiative that promotes African cultures and languages. At ATELEWO, we believe that the future of the world is both Tech and Youth, and if we want to preserve and promote African culture and languages, we need to create the right environments for young people to develop assets so they can take up the agency for the responsibilities around building for culture. As an organisation, we have always thrived on public support and we are only able to get here because of the support weâ€™ve been receiving. We are hereby calling on the public for support and partnership so we can continue to do the works we are doing for the promotion of language and culture. We can be reached at egbeatelewo@gmail.com or 07061282516.
